li: Search the application code for references to innerHTML. Ideally, there should be no such references.

If innerHTML is being used: Make sure that it is absolutely necessary and that additional safe-guards are in place to prevent those innerHTML references from being abused in cross-site scripting attacks. The three common safe-guards against cross-site scripting (XSS) are: data validation before processing data, data encoding for the correct context either before being displayed or before being stored, and data sanitization applied before displaying data. Usually, all three of these safe-guards must be layered together, in order to provide defense-in-depth.

Find all references to innerHTML. Search application code for all references to the innerHTML property. Create a spreadsheet to list all code that uses the innerHTML property to assign values to DOM elements.

Use textContent instead of innerHTML. Using the spreadsheet as a guide, for all code that uses innerHTML to assign values, change it to use textContent instead. Simply replace references to innerHTML with textContent. For most applications, no further changes should be required.

html:
Applies To

  • HTML5

What to Do

Verify that the textContent property is used instead of innerHTML to assign values to DOM elements.

Why

Using the textContent property instead of innerHTML prevents cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks, because values assigned using textContent will not be executed as script.

How to Check

To verify that the textContent property is used instead of innerHTML:

  1. Search the application code for references to innerHTML. Ideally, there should be no such references.
  2. If innerHTML is being used: Make sure that it is absolutely necessary and that additional safe-guards are in place to prevent those innerHTML references from being abused in cross-site scripting attacks. The three common safe-guards against cross-site scripting (XSS) are: data validation before processing data, data encoding for the correct context either before being displayed or before being stored, and data sanitization applied before displaying data. Usually, all three of these safe-guards must be layered together, in order to provide defense-in-depth.

How to Fix

To use the textContent property instead of innerHTML:

  1. Find all references to innerHTML. Search application code for all references to the innerHTML property. Create a spreadsheet to list all code that uses the innerHTML property to assign values to DOM elements.
  2. Use textContent instead of innerHTML. Using the spreadsheet as a guide, for all code that uses innerHTML to assign values, change it to use textContent instead. Simply replace references to innerHTML with textContent. For most applications, no further changes should be required.

Web Messaging Guidelines

  • Do Not Evaluate Messages as Code
  • Use element.textContent to Assign Values to DOM Elements
  • Explicitly State the Expected Origin with postMessage
  • Validate Data Received by Event Handlers
  • Validate the Origin Attribute Against the FQDN
  • Check The Origin Attribute of Messages
